aws::graph::propositions: # Beech HAWKER 900XP Hard Landing Accident in San Juan, Puerto Rico
The accident occurred in San Juan, Puerto Rico.
The accident occurred on January 3, 2020, at 10:40 Local time.
The aircraft involved was a Beech HAWKER 900XP.
The defining event was a hard landing.
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Executive/Corporate.
The accident number was ERA20CA073.
The aircraft registration was N805D.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage.
There were 5 people on board the aircraft.
No injuries were reported in the accident.
The pilot and copilot were conducting an instrument approach to the runway.
As the airplane was about to touch down, the pilot reduced the engine power.
The airplane descended after the pilot reduced engine power.
The airplane landed hard on a grassy area short of the runway threshold.
The fuselage sustained substantial damage.
The pilot reported there were no preaccident mechanical malfunctions with the airplane.
The pilot reported there were no preaccident mechanical failures with the airplane that would have precluded normal operation.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the probable cause of the accident.
The probable cause was the pilot's failure to maintain a proper descent rate during landing.
The pilot's failure to maintain proper descent rate resulted in a hard landing short of the runway.
The National Transportation Safety Board identified "Aircraft control - Pilot" as a personnel issue finding.
The National Transportation Safety Board identified "Descent rate - Not attained/maintained" as an aircraft finding.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
San Juan, Puerto Rico

## Date & Time: 
January 3, 2020, 10:40 Local

## Aircraft:
Beech HAWKER 900XP

## Defining Event:
Hard landing

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Executive/Corporate

## Accident Number:
ERA20CA073

## Registration:
N805D

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Injuries:
5 None

## Analysis

As the pilot and copilot of the business jet were conducting an instrument approach to the runway and as the airplane was about to touch down, the pilot reduced the engine power. The airplane then descended and landed hard on a grassy area short of the runway threshold. The fuselage sustained substantial damage. The pilot reported that there were no preaccident mechanical malfunctions or failures with the airplane what would have precluded normal operation.

## Probable Cause and Findings

The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this accident to be:

The pilot's failure to maintain a proper descent rate during landing, which resulted in a hard landing short of the runway.

## Findings

| Personnel issues | Aircraft control - Pilot |
| --- | --- |
| Aircraft | Descent rate - Not attained/maintained |

---
